title: Can maternal immunization save more newborns?
author: Keith Klugman Director; Pneumonia; Bill; Melinda Gates Foundation
description: Two infections claim the lives of 200,000 infants each year. A unique vaccination method could reverse these tragic numbers.
cleaned_text: More on maternal immunization Two mothers, one preventable infection At the Gates Foundation, we are striving toward a world where no parent loses a child to a preventable disease. Two mothers, one from upstate New York in the United States, and one from Johannesburg, South Africa, shared their stories with us. One vaccination, three incredible benefits Maternal immunization is poised to help many more infants survive. One pediatrician-turned-researcher has made this area of medical innovation his life's work. Read next [Explainer: Four things to know about RSV](/ideas/articles/rsv-explained-four-things-to-know-about-this-surging-virus) A Gates Foundation expert speaks about the surging virus, its effects on lower-income countries, and when we might expect a vaccine. [Time well spent: The complex journey of a life-saving vaccine ](/ideas/articles/creating-life-saving-pcv-vaccine-for-pneumonia-india) The story of how a life-saving vaccine called PCV was rolled out to every child in India—in record time, at low cost, and during a pandemic—illustrates what's possible in global health. [This may be the best 'medicine' in newborn care](/ideas/articles/kangaroo-mother-care-neonatal-skin-to-skin-contact) A low-tech intervention—skin-to-skin contact with the mother—is improving outcomes for premature and low-birth-weight newborns around the world, even during the pandemic.
